property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: Service members meeting with Afghan counterparts

note.text: Your conversations with Afghans might be less direct than you're used to. If you ask, "Will the project be done by Thursday?" or "Is your team prepared?," your counterpart may reply by saying "inshallah." The term expresses uncertainty and may not always mean “yes.” Afghans might use it to avoid giving a negative answer.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: Afghan and U.S. service members discussing the details of a mission

note.text: Rather than asking, "Is your team prepared?," you might have more success asking "How prepared is your team?" You may get more information by asking an open-ended question, which allows you to discuss details further.

property.name: mediadisplayblurb
property.value: An Afghan service member discussing events with a tribal leader

note.text: Showing anger, raising your voice in front of others, or reacting negatively to setbacks is considered extremely rude and a sign of weakness. Afghans appreciate those who speak in a clear, moderate voice. Keep a calm and deliberate approach, even if you are frustrated by your progress.
